subject: American pronunciation
msgSnippet: Correct me if I m wrong, but I get the impression that Quikscript has developed standard Quikscript spellings based on American pronunciations. I speak British
messageBody:
Correct me if I'm wrong, but I get the impression that Quikscript has
developed standard Quikscript spellings based on American
pronunciations.

I speak British English, although I'm perfectly comfortable hearing
American English. When it comes to spontaneously writing Quikscript,
however, I write the British way, and have had cause for pause while
reading examples of Quikscript spelt the American way. Of course, the
difficulty lasts just a moment, but the experience gave rise to the
reflection that one of the factors that makes English a worldwide
language is that the spelling (however atrociously complicated and
irregular) is understood all over the English-using world, (despite
discrepancies betwen Ameican and English spellings). Differences in
pronunciation don't come in the way. For example, while I find it hard
to understand Australian speech, I have no problems with Australian
English as expressed in newspapers or internet sites.

I remember the story of the Australian who woke up in a hospital bed
and saw a friend in the next bed. He asked, "Did you come here to
die?" Replied his friend, "Yes, to die!" For any who have never heard
an Australian speaking, the dialogue went thus: "Did you come here
today?" "Yesterday."

Imagine an Australian writing the words "today" and "yesterday" in
Quikscript the way he pronounces it! Neither the Englishman nor the
American would be likely to guess what it means.

What do you feel about standardizing Quikscript spellings to the sound
of British English? The argument in favor would be that it is
understood in all the former British colonies, probably including the
USA.
